The message is meaningful and delivered in an unique way
Sometimes the wisest is the naivest

The story starts as alien enter earth knowing nothing about the planet. He has the ability to read a person just by touching him/her. He wears a pendant which is the link to his planet. He goes through every nook and corner of certain parts of North India. Then he meets a money minded priest to whom people fall on his feet considering him as the 'Shiva of Meluha'. But then,this priest guy takes away the pendant from pk, and tells to the world that this tiny little necklace has divinely powers(brilliant marketing strategy). Anushka Sharma, BTW supports the Pk guy the whole time, as she becomes the only true friend to him.This poet loving girl falls in love with a guy offshore, but feels the love was unrequited. The rest of the story is about pk winning the game and Anushka winning her guy.The legendary acting by Aamir Khan and brilliant direction by Hirani makes this movie an interesting piece for the society. " PK "Director: Rajkumar Hirani Cast: Aamir Khan, Anushka Sharma, Boman Irani, Sushant Singh Rajput, Sanjay Dutt.Rajkumar Hirani is back in the multiplexes after a five-year hiatus and the wait has been worth it.PK, the writer-director's fourth directorial venture, is a wonderful piece of cinema that, pretty much like his much-loved Munnabhai films, blends heart and head with commendable mastery .PK is a fearless critique of religious bigotry and the ways of India's proliferating Godmen, but the film's message is shorn of rancour and bitterness. It is instead cloaked in humanity and humour, which accentuates its impact no end.The screenplay, written by Hirani and Abhijat Joshi, takes make-believe elements on one hand and draws upon the realities of our times on the other to deliver a fantasy so unique and original that it takes your breath away.PK delivers an entertaining tale that touches upon the social and political ills that plague us but it does so without falling out of line with the need to keep the story simple and straightforward.PK is a film that restores one's faith in the much maligned Bollywood idiom. It demonstrates that the so-called clichéd conventions of Mumbai's popular cinema can, in hands as able as Hirani's, yield entertainment of the very highest pedigree.The film opens in the desert of Rajasthan where a stark naked alien (Aamir Khan) alights from a spaceship looking lost and forlorn. He belongs to a planet where clothing is unheard of and words as we earthlings know them are redundant because its inhabitants need nothing more than pure thaughts to communicate.A theft leaves him stranded and the extra-terrestrial begins a search for the remote control device that he needs to communicate with his spaceship. His adventures on earth bring him in contact with a jovial Rajasthani band master Bhairon Singh (Sanjay Dutt), a spunky television journalist Jaggu Sahni (Anushka Sharma), and a greedy head of a religious cult, Tapasvi Maharaj (Saurabh Shukla).He learns how to survive on our hostile planet, but what he imparts to those he meets along the way is far more valuable than anything that the latter can give him. PK is a film that is marked by purity of vision and precision of storytelling. It is funny, feel-good and thaught provoking .Thanks to the finely etched characters that they are called upon to play, the actors have their jobs significantly simplified. They do not need to rise above the level of the writing. The benchmark is set for them, and they simply have to ensure that they measure up. All of them do just that. Aamir Khan is of course the dynamo that propels the narrative, but Anushka Sharma, too, gives it her best shot. Sushant Singh Rajput plays only a minor role in the film as the heroine's Pakistani boyfriend from her days in Bruges, Belgium, but he makes the most of the limited opportunities that he gets.The villain in PK isn't your average Bollywood baddie. He is a godman who thrives on the incredulity of his followers, but when confronted with the prospect of being shamed on the set of a television show, he does not unleash a battery of goons as such characters are wont to do in a Hindi movie.PK is, after all, a Rajkumar Hirani film, and nothing that it delivers hinges on devices that have done to death. It springs surprises at every turn, not the least among of which is a very special appearance by Ranbir Kapoor.This is an absolutely unmissable mass entertainer, if ever there has been one. It is unlikely that you will ever be more entertained and more enlightened - both at the same time - by a Bollywood film.

His adventures on earth bring him in contact with a jovial Rajasthani band master Bhairon Singh (Sanjay Dutt), a spunky television journalist Jaggu Sahni (Anushka Sharma), and a greedy head of a religious cult, Tapasvi Maharaj (Saurabh Shukla).He learns how to survive on our hostile planet, but what he imparts to those he meets along the way is far more valuable than anything that the latter can give him. PK is a film that is marked by purity of vision and precision of storytelling. It is funny, feel-good and thaught provoking .Thanks to the finely etched characters that they are called upon to play, the actors have their jobs significantly simplified. They do not need to rise above the level of the writing. The benchmark is set for them, and they simply have to ensure that they measure up. All of them do just that. Aamir Khan is of course the dynamo that propels the narrative, but Anushka Sharma, too, gives it her best shot. Sushant Singh Rajput plays only a minor role in the film as the heroine's Pakistani boyfriend from her days in Bruges, Belgium, but he makes the most of the limited opportunities that he gets.The villain in PK isn't your average Bollywood baddie. He is a godman who thrives on the incredulity of his followers, but when confronted with the prospect of being shamed on the set of a television show, he does not unleash a battery of goons as such characters are wont to do in a Hindi movie.PK is, after all, a Rajkumar Hirani film, and nothing that it delivers hinges on devices that have done to death. It springs surprises at every turn, not the least among of which is a very special appearance by Ranbir Kapoor.This is an absolutely unmissable mass entertainer, if ever there has been one. It is unlikely that you will ever be more entertained and more enlightened - both at the same time - by a Bollywood film.

reviews.review_title: Without going for "God help me!", go for "All is well" and give it your best!
reviews.content: 'Bhagwaan hai kahaan re tu...' gave me goosebumps all over my body and my eyes were wet! I was literally thrilled. What a masterpiece Raju Hirani has created on celluloid! And hats off to Aamir Khan. It takes a lot of courage to make such a statement in this country as pk does. Challenging the stupid norms and rituals that our society has been teaching us for ages is like catching a star in the night sky and trying to push it towards the moon. You can think like you are actually doing it but it really never happens. So will be the case with pk. All of us will watch pk, realize what foolish activities we keep on doing everyday, laugh at ourselves, and continue doing the same activities. It is not going to affect our lifestyle in any way. But still pk is a very special film due to two primary factors. First, Aamir Khan. What a remarkable performance! It does not get better than this; performance of a lifetime! If you think Hrithik Roshan's portrayal of Rohit in Koii Mil Gaya is the best performance by any actor in a 'special' character, Aamir's pk will surely make you doubt that. The sanity and the dedication with which he has performed every scene in the film is simply mesmerizing. Second, Rajkumar Hirani, of course. His direction is superb. But the screenplay and editing is not perfect. A few scenes are rushed and abrupt. The Sushant-Anushka love plot has been dealt in a great hurry, which looks odd. Sanjay Dutt's lovable act could also have been a bit longer. But pk is very much Hirani's film and he proves once again what a fantastic story-teller he is! All said and done, pk is not a 10/10 film for me. There are a few disappointing reasons why. First, the antagonist, played by Saurabh Shukla, is not strong enough. It seems like an enlarged enactment of the actor's 'Batuk maharaj' from Lagey Raho Munna Bhai. Being the brand ambassador of all-the-stupid-stuff-happening-around, Tapasvi ji should have been a much stronger character. Second, the climax is hurried and not a very convincing conclusion to the issue has been put forward. I don't mean to say that the climax is bad. But it's just about okay. It could have been much better. Bottomline: pk is a film which none would even dare to make! And here they have made it and I don't know how! It is a very difficult film to make and has been made with near perfection. pk in my view is definitely the best entertainer in the last 5 years (post 3 idiots). One of Bollywood's best offerings!

reviews.review_title: American's Review of the Bollywood Hit
reviews.content: If you are American and wondering whether this movie is worth the watch, let me fill you in. I have seen roughly 10-15 Indian films, most of which populated the Top 250 at one point or another. This is what brought me to watch PK. I've enjoyed several other movies featuring Aamir Khan, particularly "3 Idiots." I didn't enjoy PK as much as 3 Idiots, but this one came close.PK is the story of an alien who lands on Earth. Shortly after, his remote required for the return journey is stolen and he is told that "God only knows" where the remote went. Thus, the alien embarks on a quest to meet God and find his remote, attempting various religions and practices to achieve his goals.The movie is at times funny, serious, heartwarming, etc. as seems to be standard from Bollywood. I certainly enjoyed the ride, but it may take a few Indian films before you are comfortable with the style.The premise is very exciting, as we get to witness a true outsider and his discovery of religion and belief systems in our world. I was impressed with the movie for handling a topic of such potential controversy, and I was pleasantly surprised with the film's final conclusion. I am sure that some viewers, like many of the characters in PK, perceived this discussion as an attack on religion or beliefs. But I think the film only encourages us to question the things that we are willing to do to promote our own religion, sometimes at the expense of others. This film shouldn't discourage you from your beliefs; rather it should inspire you to do things that are best for yourself and for others.I would certainly recommend this film to anyone, and I don't think it's a movie that's only enjoyable to Indian viewers. Indian, American, or otherwise, you should give this movie a shot.

We've often heard ourselves say, "Do not judge a book by its cover". But, deep down, we always judge, regardless of what we say or believe. It is pointless to argue otherwise, it is one of our instincts.I myself am no exception. I was. at first, very reluctant to watch this movie. When I was asked if I would want to go to watch it, I insisted otherwise. I had seen some Indian movies which were not up to par. Some, really bad, too. But, a few rotten apple don't spoil the barrel. I was forced to go (Which is debatable). But, I am glad I went. This movie is a great flick. It tackles some of the most primitive questions. While the plot may have loops, it's questions surrounding religion, morality and religious discrimination cover up for it . Without going into too much detail, I would urge you to try to watch this movie. This movie would make you question morality, and the baffling holy war this world has gone into. Who's to blame? Though the answers may vary from creed to creed, the answer would be of the same essence. Is one creed really to be blamed? r do we all share a part of the blame? This movie may not be one of those types which would shake you down to your core and have action that would make you sit at the edge of your seat, it still would dive deep in your brain and heart, and be there with you.A great job with directing, and acting. It's comic, yet, amazingly rhetorical depiction of the confusion surrounding this world was beyond words. A very well written and acted movie with a promising idea.

After stepping out of a Rajkumar Hirani film, one is usually overcome with feelings of optimism for the future; be it Munnabhai MBBS, Lage Raho Munnabhai, or 3 Idiots, each time he has managed to passionately uproot an impeding social issue in Indian society and present solutions to us through good-natured comedy and emotion. The result usually leaves one with the desire to at the very least think more about, if not contribute, to the issue at hand. Now don't get me wrong - PK is by no means a bad film. Rest assured all of the aforementioned elements are present here and in great abundance. Yet for some reason, it lacks the punch that the previous 3 films left you with. Why? Read on to find out. The film begins with an alien (Aamir Khan) being left by his spaceship in a Rajasthan desert. While he is navigating around, his tracking device is stolen by a thief who mistakes it to be an expensive piece of jewelry. Without the device, the alien cannot go home, so he wanders around the neighboring villages searching for the device, picking up subtle cultural nuances along the way. He stumbles upon Bhairon Singh (Sanjay Dutt) who guides him through the desert and leads him to go to Delhi to search for the device. Upon reaching Delhi, he is mistakenly named "PK" and runs into Jagat Janani aka "Jaggu" (Anushka Sharma), a reporter who's on the prowl for an exciting story. Jaggu eventually comes to acknowledge that PK is an alien, and helps him to retrieve his device on a quest that involves great revelations about love, religion, spirituality and life in general. Now one may ask why my summary didn't address any of the religious themes that the film is being so greatly acclaimed for. The fact is that revealing these themes will subtract from the little novelty the film has to begin with. Unfortunately, PK is quite frankly, Hirani's weakest script to date; however, the reason behind this is not the fault of the screenwriters themselves but the coincidence of "OMG: Oh My God" releasing first. The punch that I had mentioned earlier is reduced to a great extent by the various similarities that PK shares with OMG, especially in the second half. While the manner in which Hirani tackles these issues is without a doubt intriguing, it simply feels like deja vu of the prior film. For instance, the innocence of PK's character being manipulated by the "managers" (as described in the film) of religion hearkens back to Paresh Rawal's character crusading (albeit in a humorous way) against the corrupt self-proclaimed gurus. Other weaknesses in the film include moments that are too drastic in comparison to the overall mood of the film, taking away from the flow of the story. At one moment, the audience is laughing like there's no tomorrow and the next moment is expected to be overwhelmed with emotion. The transitions lack any sort of smoothness. In addition, the music is little more than mediocre, with the exception of the catchy "Tharki Chokro", courtesy of guest composers Ajay- Atul. Music has never been a strong point of Hirani's films; Shantanu Moitra's songs for Lage Raho Munnabhai and 3 Idiots were far too minimalist; they seemed better suited for a minute-long ad jingle and lacked the opulence of a classic Bollywood soundtrack. The same goes for PK; the songs have the same structure and arrangements as Hirani's previous films and are almost sleep- inducing. I felt like I was listening to a CD of 3 Idiots on repeat! And the lyrics by Swanand Kirkire and Amitabh Varma are atrocious; words like "Tinga Tinga Nanga Punga" and "Love Is A Waste of Time" are enough proof of the level of lyrics we have here. It's time that Hirani start considering names like A.R Rahman, Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy, and Gulzar in order to improve upon this weakness. The other major weakness is Anushka Sharma; while Hirani's films have never been known for great female roles (the exception being Kareena Kapoor in 3 Idiots), Anushka is unable to make much of the little work she is given and simply repeats her irritating bubbly Punjabi girl act that we have seen her do in virtually every film. It's time she brought some variety to her performances if she wants to be remembered. Now don't freak out. While the list of grievances may be long, they are no match for the sheer brilliance of the one and only Mr. Perfectionist Aamir Khan. The man has this capability to turn even the worst of scripts into pure gold. Heck, he was even able to shine in "Dhoom 3" - and PK's script is rest assured much, much better than that! Aamir Khan breathes life and soul into the character of PK. From his spot-on expressions and body language to his crisp Bhojpuri dialogue delivery, he is a delight to watch. While this may not be his best performance in comparison to "3 Idiots" or "Taare Zameen Par", it is undoubtedly a performance to be remembered. Sanjay Dutt is delightful as the jovial Bhairon Singh; sadly, his role is far too short, most likely as a result of his jail sentence. Boman Irani as the well-meaning yet timid news anchor also provides great support. The supporting cast, many repeated from 3 Idiots, have also fared quite well. Of course, last but not least, Rajkumar Hirani does succeed as a director despite the many other flaws. His trademark wit and intelligence are present here in great form, and do provide for an enjoyable time. One thing is certain; PK is by no means a competitor to 3 Idiots. However, considering the other processed trash that has made the 100/200 crore club this year, it is a diamond in the rough. That alone warrants a viewing in the theater.

Anushka looks a bit odd in.her new look but acts brilliantly well. Sanjay Dutt is adorable in.his short role. Shaurabh Shukla is highly effective.The first half builds up the pace with crazy situations and teasing.questions... while the second half quite.nicely soothes things down. The last 20 minutes or so are.just AMAZING and take.the viewer to.new.emotional heights.Overall, this was the best bollywood movie of 2014.In the movie's own language... i dialed the 'right number' when i opted to watch this beautiful piece of cinema.

The story and the treatment improve dramatically during this part and uplift the entire thing, and you again and again admire Amir Khan, man! what a performance. Why?!!! :(((((((( I literally closed my eyes out of embarrassment of the ending. reviews.review_title: RK Hirani and VV Chopra's Indian Bildungsroman !!!!!
reviews.content: Yes. Bildungsroman!!!! That is what PK is. Woven in magical realism and abstract themes, PK is, at its heart, a tale of growing up and understanding life as it is. And the Hirani/Chopra duo flawlessly depict the very same in a rugged Indian context. The nude scene of Aamir Khan (an integral part of the movie) and many more such scenes bear testimony to the real theme of the movie, which has been assiduously wrapped in a commercial blanket by the auteur RK Hirani. As a human being ages, his/her mental condition and understanding of the society/world at large undergoes numerous phenomenological changes, most fundamentally from compliance to cognizance and finally to deeper consciousness. This is what RK Hirani/VV Chopra portray in this movie, scene after brilliant scene. Now, a bit on the actors. A well chosen cast, appreciable screenplay and soothing music coupled with the "P"erfectionist "K"Han (I have a lingering doubt if the movie title actually alluded to Aamir's sobriquet) make for a kill. PK is a brave movie, a social satire and a call to change. India has seen numerous reformers from the Buddha, Nanak, Kabir, Shankardeva, Veerashaivas, to the modern day Dayanand Saraswati, Ishwar C Vidyasagar, Pandit Nehru, Gandhi , Ambedkar , Goparaju Ramachandra Rao, Jyotibha Phule, Ram Manohar Lohia et al. And each pro-changer has been humiliated, abused and villainized in his time by the no-changer conservative orthodoxy(though later they have tried appropriating the very legacy of these great men, once their greatness gets accepted by all and sundry). What we are witnessing today, the criticism of PK and the cynical attitude towards its message, is the old phenomena (the one I mentioned in the previous sentence) being played out over and over again. All it indicates is that PK is on its way to become a cult-classic, very much like "2001-A space odyssey" and "The Seventh Seal" et al. A simple question to those complaining of PK being "anti-Hindu" . The current government of India and your PM swear by hindutva. So, what exactly is stopping them from banning PK?

The content of the movie is a very sensitive one. Love for God, which when human beings try and condense in words, unfortunately turns into dogmatic Religion. reviews.review_title: It's a courageous film that sticks to Hirani's well-oiled formula!!!!
reviews.content: Two films may be too few to base a theory on, but it does appear that in Aamir Khan and Rajkumar Hirani, Bollywood has found an actor/director pair committed to telling brave, relevant stories, the sort rarely tackled in mainstream popular cinema. After delivering a well-aimed kick in the pants to our myopic, rote- learning education system in 2009's colossally successful 3 Idiots, the team returns with PK, a film with very big...ahem...testicles. Operating in a country famously over-sensitive about religion, they've made a movie that brazenly ridicules our blind faith in god, and exposes the manipulations of godmen who feed off it for profit.These truths are skillfully illustrated when seen through the eyes of an 'outsider', the film's otherworldly hero, PK (played by Khan), who shows up quite literally in his birthday suit. PK speaks Bhojpuri, and has bulging eyes that seldom blink, arched eyebrows, protruding ears, and blood-red lips from permanently chewing paan. In the film's terrific first half, we watch as PK tries desperately to recover an item of great value to him that has been stolen. When he's told that only God can help him, he sets off earnestly to find God, discovering in the process our hypocrisies, our prejudices and our misguided obsession with religion.Hirani and his co-writer Abhijat Joshi craft clever scenes rich in irony, like one in which PK arrives at a church service with a pooja ki thali, or one in which he attempts to enter a mosque bearing wine. It's to the writers' credit that they successfully mine laughs out of scenarios that might otherwise appear prickly. We're introduced to other characters along the way, including a well-meaning bandmaster (Sanjay Dutt) who befriends PK early on in Rajasthan. In Delhi, he encounters TV news reporter, Jaggu (Anushka Sharma), who's at first fascinated by his idiosyncrasies, then promises to help recover what belongs to him when she learns his full story. But the screenplay weakens post intermission, when the stage is set for a (televised) confrontation between PK and smarmy godman Tapasvee (Saurabh Shukla). Hirani lays it on thick in these portions, and to be fair much of this territory was covered already in the Paresh Rawal starrer Oh My God. Moreover, the entire climax is hinged on a plot contrivance that sticks out in an otherwise compelling film. A hastily pasted-on romantic track between PK and Jaggu feels entirely out-of-place. Fortunately these speed-bumps don't derail Hirani's film, because even when the script fails, his leading man doesn't. Aamir Khan is riveting, and consistently endearing as the child-man who poses impossibly innocent questions that sting. Never reducing the character to caricature - despite his innumerable tics - Aamir delivers one of his best performances here. PK sticks faithfully to Hirani's well-oiled formula, and yet there is no question that it's a courageous film. Packed with sharp dialogue and genuinely funny moments that offset the lack of subtlety, it is easily one of the year's better films.Its the director's best since Lage Raho Munnabhai.

The management of AMC Rio in Gaithursburg, MD made all the desis stand in a queue, which was marked as "for PK audience". Our desperation for getting into the auditorium to occupy the most prime seat and reserve 10 more of those for our friends probably was their reason for such improvisation to let us behave and not do a black Friday door-busters during Christmas. While a couple of hundreds of us were waiting in the line checking out respective facebook or whatsapp accounts the previous show finished and another few hundreds of our clan started coming out of the multiplex. I was looking at them as if they were the winners of some sort of award, and me being a latecomer to the show whose turn didn't come yet.After about three hours when I came out of the multiplex I saw the same line of the fellow desis waiting for the next show. And now again I looked at them as bunch of lucky folks who are on their way to have a joyride full of fun, laughter, emotion, drama and many other feel- good emotions. And to top it all they are going to have this joyride named PK for the first time in their life. I, on the other had, can and will take this ride again but that won't bring me the thrill of the "first time", just like the thrills of so many intimate and personal first times of one's life. So here you go, I recommend you one of the most enjoyable movies that I have seen in my life, PK, a movie that exceeded my expectation in all aspects. By now it is probably needless to say that a movie studded with Aamir Khan, Rajkumar Hirani, Bidhu Vinod Chopra, Sanjay Dutt, Boman Irani, Saurav Shukla, Anuska Sharma and Sushant Singh Rajput is supposed to be a good one anyway, but what I (and my family and friends) got in return was a 24-carat jewel that any actor/director/producer dreams to make at least once in their lifetime.For sure I am not going to tell you the story. You know I am kind of conservative, but please be alert as every single friend of yours or the websites you visit or the blogs you read may not be so orthodox in keeping the story to themselves. So if any of those liberals will tell you the summary of PK in three lines (it is absolutely possible to do a three line summary) then half of the fun will be gone anyway. But even if you are left with the other half only, that should be more than the fun you got from all the Bollywood movies released in 2014 put together.However let me also tell you there is a chance that you might not actually find PK as enjoyable as I found it, as you might be the one who found cotton candy boring in your childhood or preferred to sit in the hotel the entire time while holidaying in a sea-resort. I am trying not to be judgmental, but surely there are some folks out there who might actually hate PK. There is already a couple of hash-tags to boycott PK circulating in the virtual world. So in case you love to experience something different, welcoming to new concepts, ideas and questions and love to laugh your heart-out PK is your movie. And in case you are a staunch believer of the concept that AIDS can be cured by doing kapalbhati five-times-a-day there is another movie coming soon for you, which you might like and you can watch the trailer at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4OTT9T1Px4.Folks go to your nearest movie theater at the first opportunity you get, watch PK and have fun !

I went to watch this movie in 3rd week. After reading reviews and people opinions I was expecting some type of masterpiece. In the process he finds too much confusion in searching the GOD and finally able to find true meaning of GOD. He preaches about the real religion and GOD. I must say that the movie was entertaining and engaging. The screen play and plot was good but with lot of loopholes. It is not as tight as 3 Idiots or MunnaBhai series where each scene is justified in the overall frame of movie. And as someone has pointed out the character development is not good. The characters are in single direction and gives the feeling of fairy tale rather than a thought provoking movie. I suggest to watch Oh My GOD which has handled the topic in much better way than pk. The acting was good. But some brilliant actors are wasted such as Boman Irani and Brijendra Kala. I was expecting more footage for them. Anushka Sharma was okay but nothing extra-ordinary.Same can be said about Sushant Singh Rajput. Sanjay Dutt was good. Amir Khan was superb. I am from Bhojpuri region and I can say that he has got his bhojpuri accent quite well. Anushka- Sushant love angle was forced and was not engaging. The last scene of the movie was pathetic where we are trying to search the meaning of true religion and GOD by some TV show and some cross- border telephone connection. There should be better way to handle it. You can watch this movie for some genuine laugh and comic scenes but should not be treated anything above that.

reviews.review_title: Rajkumar Hirani's first film in five years
reviews.content: Rajkumar Hirani's first film in five years is a warm, funny and piercingly provocative satire that should blow the blues away. It is the kind of full-blooded but genteel entertainer that should get us all into just the right frame of mind to usher in Christmas and bid adieu to a year that has seen us celebrate ugly excess on all fronts with unseemly glee. PK, buoyed by a magnificent script and outstanding acting all around, is an uplifting fantasy that springs a surprise at every turn but never overplays its hand. It comes as close to storytelling perfection as any mainstream Hindi movie has done in living memory.It has great songs, beautifully filmed musical set pieces, brilliant pacing and nary a moment that flags. As a cinematic send-up on Gods true and fake, PK pulls no punches at all and speaks its mind like a carefree child that has just learnt to talk and make sense of the world. But this hard-hitting critique of all that ails a nation that seems to have lost its human moorings and is in blind pursuit of false panaceas remains good-natured all the way through.The screenplay by Hirani and Abhijat Joshi demands a degree of willing suspension of disbelief, especially when it comes to a few of the pivotal coincidences that drive the narrative. The characters and the crucial dramatic and comic moments are, however, informed with such infectious warmth and beauty that nothing that the plot throws up is ever in danger of ringing overly false.The five-year hiatus between 3 Idiots and this film has clearly served them well. The screenwriters have worked a delicately crafted love story into the taut tapestry of PK, thereby lending it an emotional dimension that usually eludes a high-minded satire. Even the principal antagonist in PK, Tapasvi Maharaj, played superbly by Saurabh Shukla, isn't an ogre designed to evoke disgust.PK is out to provoke but not to shock. The film asks questions via its idiot savant protagonist, but does not attempt to deliver facile, absolute answers. And that makes it all the more effective. PK is propelled primarily by Aamir Khan's delightfully droll superstar turn as a nameless seer from outer space who is stranded on Planet Earth - in Rajasthan and Delhi to be precise.This is an unlikely saga of an alien who lands in the desert completely naked like a new-born baby and then proceeds to acquire the ways of human adults in a bid to survive in a hostile environment. His fate hinges on whether he can regain a stolen gadget that he needs in order to return to his home light years away and cling on to his purity as his brushes with mankind becomes increasingly hazardous.In one of the film's quirkiest scenes, he learns the language of humans by drawing words out of the mind of a sleepy Bhojpuri- speaking sex worker that he is led to by his only friend in the desert of Rajasthan, band master Bhairon Singh (Sanjay Dutt).

reviews.review_title: A tragic plot given a less effective medium of comedy
reviews.content: Without revealing any plot, the character of pk faces a real tragedy like when we are small and don't find our way home from the crowd. This story could have been used to influence mindsets across by building on its dark side like the opening scene promises but Hirani takes the same route he has traveled for his last two films and gets a significant amount of laughs but doesn't provide the depth of his previous two absolute masterpieces. This time, his simple humor and exotic characters couldn't hold together what he tries to portray in the film. While he does put forth a very relevant issue in our decorated but flawed Indian Culture, he relies on making the majority of audience happy by giving them a few laughs first and then get straight to controlling them by presenting the reality behind their mindset. This worked brilliantly well for lage raho and 3 idiots because the medium of comedy was well suited to the characters of munnabhai and rancho. Here there was no real need to stick to the same technique, like I said, he did get a good laughs but people unknowingly laughed to dark humor if you see the film and carefully observe the scenes in the first half of the main lead. Hirani chases humor with this story which is not comic in nature unlike his previous two where it came naturally and ends up getting distracted at times. It is difficult to get absorbed by the plot which is not multi-dimensional and relies on techniques used in previous two films. There would have been immense scope had Hirani didn't make himself constrained by need to please everyone with simple humor and a relevant topic in the society. He could have been more influential with a more darker approach to the story with strong emotions against the main character. There are positives to the films in the name of Aamir, it can't get better than this. He delivers again, this time without Hirani, he still shines brighter than the film put together. In numbers, 2/5 for Hirani and 4/5 for Aamir and Co...

As Yenn Martel said, 'that Hindus, in their capacity for love, are indeed hairless Christians, just as Muslims, in the way they see God in everything, are bearded Hindus, and Christians, in their devotion to God, are hat-wearing Muslims.'Rajkumar Hirani's PK, the highest grossing Bollywood movie has definitely earned its fame. The outline of the movie is an estranged alien on Earth (receiving a very warm welcome), who is initially on a research mission but is now trying to retrieve his stolen locket, which is a beacon to his spaceship in order to return home. First of all, hats off to the script by Hirani and Abhijat Hoshi. The much hype around the film is what got me curious in the first place. Generally, Indians scowl when they meet someone from Pakistan. Ever wondered why? The film begins with this concept. Where is the label that marks us as Asians or Europians? We are the ones who made these divisions. So is the case of religion. Now, that is a touchy subject but the movie holds no restraints to discuss this. There are two Gods; the God who created us and the God we created. Which one are we to believe in? A star studded cast comprising of Aamir Khan, Anushka Sharma, Sanjay Dutt, Boman Irani, Saurabh Shukla, Sushant Sing Rajput and even a cameo by Ranbir Kapoor keeps you hooked on. There is no time for boredom or dare I say relaxation during this movie. You will definitely have tears from laughing. Things seem to go by in a whirl but everything is crystal clear. Those questions that we try to curb in our minds are blatantly asked by PK. There are times when I ask myself, 'Why are we the way we are?' And I'm glad that the creators of this film have the same thoughts. Have you ever wondered a world without God? Aren't there times when we question His existence? As the antagonist in this story said, people would slit their wrists and jump off buildings in the absence of hope. Hope is the element that keeps us going and that is why we need God. PK raises so many questions and gets us thinking as well as relating. In my opinion, the movie portrays our minds, pure and transparent. Like PK, we come into the planet as a child with an open mind. But as we grow, we are conditioned to think and be in a particular manner. It is only a handful of us that inquire the need for segregation. One of the many quotes that stuck with me was, 'Faith is fashion related'.All the songs are very apt to the individual scenarios, and Sonu Nigam's voice was a blessing to listen to. I'd even give it another go..P.s. I found a lot of similar concepts and questions from the novel The Life of Pi. Those who have read this book and watched PK might be able to relate the two. This does not mean they have plagiarized the contents. The thoughts and actions are very raw in both the sources and they deal with same matter of religion, God and hope.

One of the best movies of Amir Khan. Gives messages again and guiding a spiritual journey. The film has been kept tightly under wraps in India, with viewers wondering if the titular character — bug-eyed and goofy, with prosthetic-ally enhanced ears — was autistic, otherworldly or even God himself.That mystery is dispelled in the first scene, when a glowing spaceship deposits him in the middle of the Rajasthani desert as part of his alien race's research project.Earthlings, of course, have no idea what to make of him, and quickly dub him PK ("pee Kay" means "after drinking," or "tipsy").When PK's one chance to return home is sabotaged, he is forced to undertake an odyssey that will direct him through the minefield of human relationships — and especially through the inexplicable rituals of religion. In one moving montage, PK joins crowds of nearly every major faith in India, from Jainism to Christianity, Sikhism, Hinduism and Islam (only Buddhists get a pass, it seems).I thought it was well filmed, very intense, and was a great film for character study. You love both characters and sympathize for PK. The acting was great as usual for Amir Khan Films.What can i say? History will judge us all...

reviews.review_title: Don't go see this Bollywood Movie ("PK")
reviews.content: That's right.. Don't go see this movie..-If you feel that religion and entertainment should not be mixed and that you do not want to get the religious (or anti-religious) message from liberal/secular actors who are out to shake your faith.-If your view of religion (specifically Hinduism) is so skin-deep that it could be hurt by anyone asking innocent questions.-if you think that your particular guru, swami, baba or spiritual leader can't stand up to questioning.-If your view of the message is always colored by who the messenger is. Would you have a different opinion if the movie was from Abhishek Bacchan or Hrithik Roshan or some other generic Hindu sounding actors (instead of Aamir Khan)?-If you strongly believe that the movie was funded by some Muslim organization or country that is out to malign Hinduism.-If you are afraid that by seeing the movie, your deeply held beliefs could be altered. I personally am under no illusion that people's minds will be changed by merely watching a movie (that too on the topic of deep rooted faith)!-If you feel that for all the time spent in the movie, on Hindu rituals and fake gurus, an equal amount of time should be spent on similar aspects of Christianity and Islam (money grubbing televangelists, molesting catholic priests, Taliban and Boko Haram should be given equal time?)-If you are offended by male actors showing off their well-toned bodies (almost) in the buff. Remember, they never show Aamir Khan totally naked. There is always a branch or a Boom box that is strategically placed. So, maybe it's the allusion to male nudity that is the problem for some folks. Meanwhile, there are several such portrayals of women which are usually met with whistles of approval. There are routine and gratuitous displays of blood and gore and disemboweled bodies in movies as well as TV news, magazines and newspapers. This seems quite acceptable. No one is worried about the negative impact of these on impressionable young ones.If you fall into any of the above categories, please DO NOT go see this movie! It will ruin your day for sure!!The movie is not attacking Hinduism. It is not even attacking all gurus, babas or spiritual teachers. It is highlighting some specific kind of babas and religious practices. Why not assume that your particular baba is the "good kind"? One who is merely preaching love for all, universal brotherhood, peace, tolerance etc. Not that kind who is always trying to relieve you of your material burdens (e.g., cash or jewelry). In fact, I understand that some of the sayings and ideas used in the movie are from popular religious teachers.This whole "alien from another star/planet" stopping by, is a very clever vehicle for the director/writer to ask some "innocent" questions about religion, faith etc., which, if asked in any other context would get you thrown out (maybe even get you beat up, just to underscore that we are "peaceful and non-violent" people). Religion generally requires that you suspend critical thinking and curiosity. The PK character does exactly the opposite in the movie.I thought that the overall treatment of the topic was fairly even handed by the writer and the director. They did not go off and question the existence of a creator. They just questioned some intermediaries (agents) between the creator and the created.If the worst thing that can happen from watching this movie is that we start questioning instead of blindly following, not just in matters of faith, but in all aspects of our life, then we will be a much more enlightened and tolerant society.Sure, that whole affair with Sarfaraz in the beginning and the melodrama at the end with the conference call with Pakistani consulate staff seemed too sappy and formulaic! But, hey.. this is still a Bollywood movie and you just have to take certain aspects of it on blind faith (in the director's abilities to satisfy box-office appeal). Couple of the song and dance sequences looked good on the big screen but none of them so catchy that I would remember after a day.All in all, it was a thoroughly enjoyable and funny movie. A perfect dessert after a sumptuous New Year's lunch! Compared to Aamir's earlier movies, I would rank this slightly below "Taare Zamin Par" and "3 Idiots."As we walked out, we heard the conversation of couple of older white ladies who were in the theater with us "Wow! What a wonderful movie", "What a great way to start the New Year!", "I wonder why it only got 87% on the Rotten Tomatoes website?" One of them even asked me as we exited the theater, "How did you hear about this movie?", before we could ask them that same question!!If you have not seen the movie and if you are currently blasting the movie (and/or vandalizing movie theaters in India) for its negative portrayal of your particular religion (based on inciting views from others), then please DO NOT go see this movie, as it could sap the energy out of your righteous indignation!!

reviews.review_title: Delightful, Entertaining, Thought-Provoking.... The Film of the Decade!
reviews.content: Mr. Aamir Khan, honestly speaking, you never cease to amaze me. I had once thought that you had reached the pinnacle of your career with films such as Lagaan, RDB, TZP and 3 Idiots, and that you simply cannot get any better than what you had already done in the past. But I was wrong. PK takes everything to newer and greater heights. It is an incredibly superior cinematic journey than all the four films mentioned above, and much more than that. I am still in a daze. It is rare for me to come back home at 1-30 in the night and immediately pen down my feelings. But I just cannot help it, because it is that kind of a movie!Mind you, this movie is not for you if you are offended when somebody questions your blind beliefs and superstitions. It is not for you if you think that human beings can be segregated and divided based on artificial barriers of caste, creed and religion. It is not for you if you believe that keeping a 100 rupees note in front of a lifeless statue is more worthwhile than keeping it in front of a starving little child. It is not for you if you identify with a fellow human being because he is Hindu/ Muslim / Christian/ Sikh, but not because he is simply a fellow human being who deserves to be loved.But yes, this is YOUR kind of movie if you simply believe that 'Humanity' is the greatest religion of all. This is YOUR kind of movie if you believe that divinity is present inside each of us, and that loving the people who surround us is equivalent to worshiping a thousand gods.So take your pick and choose wisely. Once you've made your choice in the affirmative, don't waste a moment's time before catching up on what could very well turn out to be the film of the decade!

reviews.review_title: Laughter Roller Coaster- A yet another original Hirani Masterpiece
reviews.content: Hirani seems to have simply mastered the art to make his audience laugh their heads off. With PK, Hirani signs off as a facile comedy director who needs no double-meaning garbage, tactically created scenes to burst his audience into laughter. With movies like Munna Bhai MBBS (2003), Lage Raho Munnabhai (2006), 3 Idiots (2009) and PK(2014) lately, he amongst the select few gifted directors far and wide, capable of delivering original, seamless piece of facetiousness that leaves you with a thought-provoking message in the end. For PK, it is one such movie that re-ignites the hope of quality in Bollywood, which for that matter has been predominantly plagued by copied, pathetic, vulgar and senseless stuff. Crisp storyline, flawless direction and amazing performances make PK one-of-its kind, not unlike Hera-Pheri. Truly, Aamir is a perfectionist and Anuskha has loads of talent. The movie has a simple story line about humane tale of love, laughter and letting-go. It shows the world from the eyes of a stranger, an Alien "Aamir Khan" this time, who asks questions that no one has asked before. Who seeks reasons for the way society has set its ways over thousand of years. The childlike curiosity of PK, supported by beautiful and smart Anushka Sharma transforms into a spiritual odyssey for him and millions of others alike. Go and do watch PK! Laugh out loud and take away some simple truths of life, we often overlook in our daily lives.

PK makes you realize that religions are formed so that people are shown a right way to live. Its not God but the people who hurt and trick fellow humans in the name of God because of their selfishness. Its a brave attempt by a director, especially to release a movie in the country with so many different religions, to convey this sensitive message in a comical way without hurting their feelings. Every childish questions asked by PK in the movie are those we forgot to ask in our life. One more kudos to the director because he has shown that America is not the only country where aliens will land, they can land on India also.

reviews.review_title: An entertaining but flawed film carried superbly by Aamir Khan
reviews.content: Although the film has few flaws in its story-telling, PK is more than watchable because of its great comic moments and for taking up a subject, Religion, which for a long time in its history, bollywood had decided to steer clear of. And there are good reasons for it. Movies which have religion as its subject matter always tend to be controversial. We are seeing the same thing with PK with many suits being filed which thankfully the courts have dismissed quickly.In a year where we have had a very short supply of quality movies, PK will come as a breath of fresh air. Just like his first three films, Rajkumar Hirani again takes up a socially relevant subject and laces it with humor and idiosyncratic situations. We would find many of Hirani's trademarks in this movie. The central character who is a misfit who gets mocked at the beginning before winning everyone's hearts one by one and ends up being the agent of change. The main antagonist is not an evil person but one who has misguided beliefs. The film is a combination of laughing-out loud moments and some tear-jerking moments.Whereas the comic moments are as laughable as was the case with Munnabhai and 3 Idiots, it is the emotional moments where it comes up short. And the major reason is that the movie doesn't devote enough time in fleshing out the relationships between the characters. Case in point, Anushka and Sushant's romance and break- up and also Anushka's relationship with his father. Also, except for Aamir and Anushka's characters, most of the supporting characters don't have much to do which is highly unfortunate for a cast with talents like Boman Irani, Saurabh Shukla and Sanjay Dutt. Another flaw is that the first half involves too many songs which breaks the flow of the story and the second half tends to get preachy at times and the ending seemed to be a bit melodramatic just like 3 Idiots.Aamir Khan's PK is the heart and soul of this movie and he comes up with arguably one of his best performance of his career alongside his performances in Lagaan, Rang De Basanti, 3 Idiots etc. Expect him to win many best actor awards in this award season although he wouldn't be attending those award functions. Anushka Sharma plays a bubbly character and she is more than efficient in this role. Sanjay Dutt is wonderful in his brief screen role. Saurabh Shukla is watchable. Boman Irani is wasted in a role who has very little to do. The writing team of 3 Idiots, Rajkumar Hirani and Abhijit Joshi, comes up with another socially relevant script and their work is top-notch although it isn't as water-tight as their previous work. The music by Shantanu Moitra is pretty good although the songs aren't as memorable as 3 Idiots. My picks are Bhagwan Kaha Hai Tu, Chaar Kadam and the PK theme.PK is not a movie which will please everyone. In fact, many will get offended due to its anti-religious views (A good example are the protests ranging in Gujarat accusing the movie of hurting Hindu sentiments). My advice to these people is not to misinterpret the message in the film. Just like the similar themed Paresh Rawal- starrer Oh My God, this movie is not telling us to stop having faith in God but it is questioning whether the medium by which we try to communicate with God is right or not. I recommend all of you to watch this movie at-least once. Whether you like it or not, you will not be able to erase this movie from your memory for a good time. And how many recent bollywood films linger in your memory even for a moment after you have finished watching it?

As his remote control was stolen straight after his arrival, he is desperate to get it back. Once he realizes that his chance are practically non existent to find his remote control, he choose to learn from the humans to seek help from god. But which one is the right one Hindu, Christian, Muslim or Sikhs god ? I found the idea to address human greed and religious hypocrisy very refreshing, however with the exception of Aamir Khan the acting was mostly abysmal throughout the movie.

reviews.review_title: Does not belong on top 250 list
reviews.content: I have been watching every movie on the top 250 list, this being the 165th. It is the only one so far I couldn't stomach to the finish. The same message was delivered again and again with the same format - PK locks his bulging idiot eyes on a stereotype from Indian culture, cue goofy music, PK approaches the person and causes a massive fuss by assessing his situation at face value without knowledge of cultural nuances. Human culture, especially religion, is full of ridiculous contradictions. I get it. For the 100th time, I get the joke, now please stop insulting my intelligence!Aside from that issue, the story was not structured properly; characters were heavily developed and then abandoned from the plot for far too long. The journey for PK to hunt for his remote was a mere vehicle to lead him through a comprehensive spreadsheet of the aforementioned stereotypes (it would not surprise me if the screenplay began life as this spreadsheet), and I was distinctly aware of that fact while watching.From a technical perspective every shot in the movie was done very well. The music scenes were amusing. Those are the only positives I can come up with.The movie's high position in the rankings comes from the vast majority of reviews, user and critic alike, originating from one demographic. It's not for me to say their taste is wrong, but they definitely were looking for something different in this movie than I was. I would warn viewers more accustomed to western culture and less with Bollywood to have a backup ready if you choose to spend your night watching this, because you might find it as disappointing as I did.

reviews.review_title: The best movie I have ever seen

reviews.review_title: The Film guides people to think logically while leading their lives
reviews.content: PK is an exceptional movie. It carries a message, asking all us all to take care of humanity rather than just religion. It provokes your thoughts and makes you think about how the world works. The movie throws light on the fact that we are so biased about people from other religions, that we often mistake the good for the bad. The Film also guides people not to be superstitious. The movie is not an attack on any Religion, it is an attack on Mankind as it exists today. It highlights the wrongdoings by the so called godmen and makes an attempt to showcase them to the world. The points raised were good but could have hurt sentiments of some groups of people. Though there are some unpredictable scenes which make the audience uncomfortable. Lord is acceptable but GOD? Why are you calling a human being god and insulting the almighty?When we try to raise our voice against such people, you are tortured mentally/physically till you stop. No religions were harmed in the making of this film. That's the gist of a title card that runs before the credits in the Hindi movie "PK," directed by Rajkumar Hirani, which states that the film doesn't intend to hurt the feelings of any community, sect or religion.And this sweet, ambling comedy about an innocent abroad - an alien who touches down in the Rajasthan desert - doesn't offend, even as it pokes gentle fun at religious differences and hypocrisy.When PK (Aamir Khan) lands in Rajasthan, naked and gym-buff, his first encounter with an earthling is a rude one. A man steals his flashing green pendant (it matches his flashing green eyes), a remote control that allows him to call his ship for pickup.After some twists and turns - including a quick, PK-less detour to Belgium for a Pakistani Romeo and Indian Juliet love story - our hero acquires language (Hindi) and finds himself in Delhi in search of his pendant. God alone, he's told, can help him.Guileless, he appeals to God in all his houses: temples, mosques, churches. Sneaking into a maternity ward, he examines an infant from top to bare bottom, looking for a label: is he Christian, Muslim, Hindu?Mr. Hirani's other films include "Lage Raho Munna Bhai" (2006), a comedy about a gangster who becomes a Gandhi-inspired good guy. That movie and its slogan, "Gandhigiri," were so successful that they ushered in a small real-life wave of Gandhian protests.It's hard to imagine that "PK," with its slogan "wrong number" (when God's interlocutors get their wires crossed), will have a similar impact. Mr. Hirani remains an excellent storyteller, weaving his disparate story strands into a convincing, satisfying whole - a rare Bollywood feat.But "PK" lacks the redemptive arc of "Lage Raho" - at least its hero does. PK, played with earnest sexlessness by Mr. Khan, who possesses one of Hindi cinema's most ogled bodies, is another man-boy innocent meant to remind us of our own corruption. He does, but so benignly, that it's hard to feel the sting.

reviews.review_title: Believe in the God who created you, not that you created.
reviews.content: It is a roaring successful film which has developed as the highest- grossing Indian film of all time and first time in Bollywood, actor and director has a charismatic pair making outstanding films telling with the brave, sensitive issues and relevant stories in the mainstream films and that is none other than Aamir Khan and Rajkumar Hirani. Both have the magic on silver screen and is proved again recently released film "PK". The movie is not only bring the sensitive mattes but also creatively portrays the character "PK" which questions against the superstitions of religions. The most sensitive and bravery is it query in a country like India where religion is so insightful and deeply entrenched and "PK" has done wonderfully. In this film, "PK" (Aamir Khan) the title role, an alien dressed birthday suit who lands on earth and shakes the world with questioning on all fallacies of religion.The main role Aamir Khan "PK" came from another planet landing on earth and lost his remote and lose the opportunity to go back to his planet. After this he is trying to probe all the misconceptions of the society with the outsider eyes. He is not belong to this earth and Aamir Khan has portrayed the character so well with questioning on the religious superstitions and fallacies. There are different cultural and communication gaps we can find in "PK"'s character because coming from other planet who doesn't know any language but learn "Bhojpuri" by transferring from a girl with holding hand. "Jaggu" (Anushka Sharma) has teamed up with PK to help himto find the remote. Jaggu is a TV reporter who is also a victim of "Tapashwee" (Saurabh Shukla) who is a religious leader. Previously "Jaggu" had a relationship with a Muslim boy named "Sarfaraz" (Sushant Singh). She then broke up because of Tapashwee who convinced her that a Muslim always betrays with Hindu. Every time "PK" called "its wrong number" when anyone is doing any superstitions or fallacies. PK's another friend "Bhairon" (Sanjay Dutt) who initially helped him. While Jaggu is going to make a live TV show where she makes conversation between Tapashwee and PK. Bhairon caught the thief who steal PK's remote and sell it to Tapashwee. Tapashwee was lying to people that the remote he found from mountain and it's belong to their one God "Shiva". So Jaggu wants to unmask Tapshwee's character to the public. "PK" has asked some questions about God that why so many religions, why different beliefs, one god or many Gods and so on. Finally he concluded this our God is only one, he is so merciful and his existence everywhere. Wherever you are how you pray he can listen you, he is not liar. But we created a fraud and fake God which is bad like us, not kind even because we people are bad and our creation of God would be like us. After that PK got the remote from Tapashwee and went back to his planet and teach the society that believe in one and only God but don't create your own Gods. The last scene Aamir Khan's ("PK") is going back to the planet but he never express his love to Jaggu because he got to know Jaggu loves Sarfraz and so he just let her go and want to see her happy. Abhijaat Joshi and Rajkumar Hirani's script and dialogues are astonishing and I have found the audience most of the time laughing, clapping and while emotional scene came being so emotional and make people cry. The story is so exciting with huge performance especially by Aamir Khan. The supporting role Anushka, Saurabh Shukla, Sanjay Dutt, Boman Irani and Sushant's performance also paint "PK's canvas so well. The climax scene while Sarfraz and Jaggu was talking over phone on live show, Sushant's expression is marvelous and overall all the performers playing their job well. From the beginning to the ending Aamir Khan (PK) played so accurately and giving mind blowing expressions and to me it is his best work in his career. I don't forget this man every time breaks the Indian Bollywood Film's record and this time PK is successfully played in worldwide. PK movie has a huge success- 6.5 billion and US$100 million. PK received two Awards out of eight Nominations at the 60th Film fare Awards. The film won five Star Guild Awards, and two Life OK Screen Awards. It is not only the most all-time top blockbuster film in Bollywood but also the highest grossing foreign film in U.S.A. "PK" is a huge answer for the stereotyped people. "PK" frequently asks questions which can give us the formula that idol worship is necessary or not. The audience can realize the portrait of God. We cannot protect the God who creates everything. In "PK", the central character "PK" who is the alien and try to probe all issues which we are used to do this and without any reason we just believe what our religious leader says. "PK" is not only a film but also a social contributor. PK is a courageous film which is a good combination of Aamir Khan and Rajkumar Hirani. PK is so successful because of Aamir Khan's magical presence and funny and sharp dialogues. I am giving 4 and half stars out of 5 stars. I recommend you to go for it. If you still not watching "PK" watch it now if you don't want to miss entertainment. Directed and Edited by: Rajkumar Hirani Cast: Aamir Khan, Anushka Sharma, Saurabh Shukla, Sanjay Dutt, Sushant Singh Rajput, Boman Irani Produced by: Vidhu Vinod Chopra and Rajkumar Hirani Written by: Abhijat Joshi, Rajkumar Hirani Cinematography: C. reviews.review_title: A fragile plot held together quite well
reviews.content: Questioning of god and god men, finally settling for the existence of god, but holding the god-men guilty; much tried and repetitive climax at a live TV show (of course, the heroin is a TV reporter which seems to be the hottest job of heroins in Indian movies these days); attempting an Indo-Pak reconciliation through a cross-border love affair that originated in Belgium; of course a couple of Hindi dances - this movie has silliness floating around all over. I don't really understand what is the hype. Oh yeah, it is Aamir Khan! Somehow, all his movies are well hyped up before release.I have to admit, somehow, all the silliness is held together quite well by the director. But, it hits the peak of silliness when 2+ hours into the movie the good guy gets to lock horns with the bad guy on a live TV show. By then, I am squirming in my seat (fyi - there was no interval where I watched it).It must be made illegal to show this movie without an interval !!Coming to the question about god - Why do some people like this interesting? What is new there? Any sensible, logical person should by now has asked these questions over and over and settled on the answer. If we are still following an organized religion, it should only be for our own quantifiable benefit. We shouldn't need a silly Hindi movie to arouse that question in us. False godman has been the subject of Hindi movies for ages. Somehow, they are still in business. Hence, that aspect of this movie is insignificant.Many of the comedy scenes are silly at their best. The much talked about scene where PK pulls the pj out of a fat man's butt is completely lame. It is a joke that has been told and heard so many times on too many platforms. It is really cheap of Hirani to steal it and hype it up so much.What else? A pan-chewing, wide-open eyed, stiff alien? Usually a good actor's role is to efficiently switch between emotions on his/her face, but in this movie, Aamir Khan's hard work is to maintain the stiff expression on his face and to deliver the dialogs in the Bhojpuri accent. He can't be credited for good acting. He definitely needs to be credited for not straying into over-acting. But, at several places, it is very clear that the frame changes abruptly when he starts to slip into over-acting. So, the director or the editor should get that credit.Others - Anushka Sharma has acted OK. Her role doesn't have any major challenges. Sanjay Dutt too - OK. No major role, but he has carried himself quite well despite the paunch that the makeup man hasn't even tried very hard to hide. Review summary - Skip the theater, wait for the DVD and watch in parts.

Peeing on the walls of the Red Fort, if its supposed to be funny, well it didn't work for me. If you found it funny, good. Enjoy.I am not opposed to the idea of cinematic liberties. But really the question is, how far can you stretch that idea.You don't go promote the movie on television, as it costs time and money. Instead you add some scenes in the movie which will create controversy and keep the movie in the limelight for a few days, which is all you need these days. Release the film on 5000-6000 screens simultaneously. Cast one of the superstars in your movie, to draw the audiences.You may have noticed that I haven't commented anything on the actual movie so far. Thats exactly the point ! These movies, be it PK or HNY or Kick or Bang Bang, have nothing to do with the actual content of the movie. Story, Screenplay, Acting, Direction, nothing matters. All these movies are sold just on one thing, HYPE.Thats how you end up with a movie like PK. Its not their audacity, its just plain belief in the audience's dumb and numb state of mind, being subjected to mediocrity all year long. Even a pretentious, clichéd, mindless, sappy piece of creation is lapped up and hailed as a masterpiece.I can compile a huge list of things that are amiss in this movie. But really, its not worth the time. And it wont make any difference now. And in any case, one can argue that this movie worked for them in spite of the loopholes. So be it. If it worked at all for someone, at whatever level, its good for them. It sucked big time, as far as I am concerned.There is a full scene devoted to the ENLIGHTENMENT of the JANTA regarding the condom ISSUE. Its pitiful that a director like Rajkumar Hirani changed tracks so shamelessly, from dealing with real issues in a real(almost) way, to this type of cheap and crude humor. One can argue that even 3 idiots had crude jokes. But there are two problems with that argument. Firstly, 3 idiots was about college students and hostel life. and secondly, in addition to the crude jokes, the film had a well written script, where every single scene, character and development was strung together perfectly. Seamlessly.PK is an ill conceived, shabbily made, overrated movie. RIP Raju Hirani the genius director. Welcome Rajkumar Hirani the money spinner - warm welcome from Farah Khan and Rohit Shetty.

reviews.review_title: There are very few movies that can make you laugh and cry with equal passion.
reviews.content: There are very few movies that can make you laugh and cry with equal passion. PK does this job stunningly well and asks us to stand still and take a good look at ourselves. To take on an issue like religion and the fake 'god-men' who use it for their own benefit, and come out with a simple yet beautiful message, takes bravado. The beautiful visuals are complemented by a soulful soundtrack. Anushka Sharma delivers a captivating performance as the female lead. Aamir Khan is an absolute joy to watch and makes one wish that if aliens did decide to come visiting, they should definitely be like 'PK'. Sushant Singh Rajput shows pure brilliance in the short scenes he is a part of. A strong story-line with a powerful social message, combined with a stellar cast and amazing direction is bound to give us a movie that will leave a long lasting impression on the heart. And that is exactly what PK does.

reviews.review_title: autistic alien confused by Indians' relationship to various gods
reviews.content: I haven't watched any bollywood movies for a while. This I watched, mainly because i had a week off, and there was nothing else to do, so when a friend rang and said 'we are going to watch PK, do you want to come' we all went.PK (like ET) wants to go home. For an alien, he is remarkably like a human with autistic spectrum behavioural disorder. He observes the absurdities of god and god related activities that abound in India, and is appropriately confused. This is exactly the response of any independent observer, but the only way the film makers could represent this point of view was by using the device of an autistic alien. If a normal human character had said the stuff he did, it would have been deemed too unbelievable (because apparently normal people can't think like that in India!). I like Amir Kahn's movies (Peepli live, Chalo Dilli, absolutely loved Delhi Belly) and I understand there is a fine line he has to tread, if he wants to make a movie like this, and keep his head attached to his neck. But the biggest disappointment for me was the pulled punch in the studio scene. The logical conclusion of PK's observations would be that there is no god, not that there are 2 sets of gods. This is a missed opportunity to put across the rationalist view point, that gods are us, as are demons. That would have made this a great movie for me. As it stands, its a bit 'meh'. 6/10, and that is being generous, on account of Anoushka's legs.

reviews.review_title: Great movie that tries to be a jack of all trades
reviews.content: OK so I had hopes watching this one. Finally got a chance to watch this. I will be honest, its a brave move to try and fit all these different things inside a 3 hours span. Different things being the varied set of emotions that make you feel happy, sad, sentimental, all in just one movie. Raju Hirani did this with 3 Idiots and he did it flawlessly. That movie was a perfect blend of all emotions and worked incredibly well in terms of entertainment and the message being passed.Unfortunately, PK is a good attempt that falls flat trying that. You have a complicated story arch of Aamir's character and how he realizes things that he does and the social message he wants to pass. With all this you now have Anushka's story arch which starts off good but suddenly is given a full stop, only to conveniently resume when the movie requires it later. I strongly think that movies like 3 Idiots and 'especially' Oh My God far surpass PK because they were successful in delivering the message they aim for. The topic picked by PK, the commercialization of religions and how one should follow true religion is way way more clear and effective in OMG. The good thing I loved about this movie though is the way Aamir's character learns the different religious rituals performed all over India by different religious sects. The way his character is written is pretty unique just the way his character was in 3 Idiots. The twist by the end is good as well but I sincerely think either Anushka's love story should have been completely dropped or should have been given more screen time.In the end, the movie tries to be a jack of all trades but fails a wee bit. Not as mesmerizing as OMG but its a worth watching movie for sure. And since the way Aamir explains how religions are being followed wrongly is more down to earth and in simpler language, I think it will be understood well by the rural parts of India as well, which is where this problem lies anyways. Congratulations on being the highest grossing Bollywood movie ever.

reviews.review_title: It is a movie dealing with the blindly following some religious practices.
reviews.content: The movie starts with Amir Khan landing on earth from a spaceship. He is an alien who has come to study the planet and inhabitants of earth. Unfortunately the remote which would take Aamir back to his planet gets stolen. Trying to adjust to this plane and searching for his remote PK lands in Delhi from where starts the actual journey of PK as a total stranger in the city of Delhi. In this journey he tries to find answers to some innocent but deep meaning questions. During this time PK finds an elder brother in Sanjay Dutt and he also teams up with Anushka Sharma challenging some old immoral religious practices.Regarding the performances Aamir Khan is again at his best with a stunning performance. He excels as an artist in the role. His fluent and effortless Bhojpuri accent is an icing on the cake. It makes the movie all the more entertaining. Anushka Sharma also gives a spectacular performance in the movie keeping the standards with Aamir. Sushant Rajput is splendid in his supporting role whereas Boman Irani seems to be given a role below his potential. He could have had a stronger role. Besides this, Sanjay Dutt carries his role with innocence yet elegance.The movie gave extremely popular songs with Shantanu Moitra, Ajay- Atul and Ankit Tiwari as music composers and Swanand Kirkire, Amitabh Varma and Manoj Muntashir as lyricists. Rajkumar Hirani repeats his success again by telling an engaging story with a message.The movie deals with the topic of religious practices irrationally carried out and Godmen. Though it seems to have similarities with Oh my God, but it does not question the existence of God, it questions the practices carried out to impress the God. With its talented task and catching story PK is surely a good entertainer.
